author: Jugando A lo Geek
comment: Garou is one of the characters that shows how a kid who wanted to be a hero changed his mind and decided to be a villain. One can actually realize the problem between heroes and popularity. Sometimes when heroes become popular, people stop thinking ''he's popular because he's a hero who saves people and defeats villains'', and start thinking ''popular people are more worthy to be heroes''. When Garou was bullied, nobody stood by his side, because his bullies were popular and everyone else, even the shitty teachers wouldn't dare to turn against who's popular and be considered an outcast.

author: Gavin Allison
comment: The best character are those who blur the line between understanding evil, and being evil, yet never being able to called as such by society as a whole. They're almost fighting with their own inherent darkness. All character growth and maturity relies on this fundamental dichotomy of human nature between civility and ethics and questionable motives and barbarism.

author: Everyday Cow
comment: Spoilers:     The deconstruction comes into play when it's revealed¬†that Garou isn't really evil at heart. He has a body count of zero and actively avoids harming innocent people, and takes mercy on kids such as Tareo and Zenko multiple times. Garou doesn't really want to do evil things, but rather wants to become the ultimate antagonist in order to force the world to focus on him and become better people that way. He believes there's too much picking on the little guys, and wants people to focus on a real threat instead of the kid who doesn't fit in, for example. Saitama slowly challenges his worldview by bringing up the fact that he's a good person who basically went with a half-hearted monster hobby because he lacked the conviction to be a hero, to be the change he really wanted to see in the world. In the end, Saitama asks him if he's okay with being a villain - Garou's facial expression very clearly says he isn't.

Then, he immediately had to take on a full strength Genos. In which he still held his ground and could've won. author: TheLink 99
comment: Garou is just so so so much more. My friends(who had only seen the first season of the anime) mocked me when I told them that the second season of One punch Man was pretty deep but Garou's character is so good. In a world where monsters are hideous and inhumane creatures it is easy to start thinking that every human is good and every villain is bad. Garou on the other hand didn't stop at  they're just monsters they don't deserve any empathy and actually questionned the justice in place and why the monsters were treated the way they were. And for that he was bullied by someone who was seen at the time as the class hero. Garou finally understood that justice wasn't based on what is wrong or good but based on strength alone. He was defeated and as such was a villain. Garou's journey is also really methaporical. He claims that he is becoming more and more of a monster yet after each fights he only grows as a person. Founding friendships, protecting kids so on and so on. The only thing that's changing about him is his strength. You could argue he's becoming less of a monster after each fight. Garou's goal is also really tied behind all that. He says that his goal is to become a true monster yet it seems very obvious that isn't the case he just wants to get stronger. Why ? because a being like him winning would prove all the flaws of the current system : humans can be just as bad as monsters or that being strong doesn't mean you're right. Garou is a critique on the general idea of the hero society that is even more accurate in a caricaturized world like One Punch Man. I think that it becomes very easy to make real life parallels about economic and legal injustices you can find in some people's life. I genuinely could write an 8 page essay on why Garou and One Punch man make one of the most relevant super hero commentary in recent fiction but I think you all got my point.

However it really is not an amazing AMV, since imo the scenes were not fitting with the music most of the Time and you left out half a ton of cutting points to make it look fluid and badass. Also it seemingly has no connection to the Lyrics, its just the fight put under an Eminem Song. Well, as i said solid but it could have been better. Keep improving buddy! :) PS: Before some People think they are cool saying its hate: nah. Its called criticism.

author: Mi Ri
comment: Ok didn't intend to write a whole ass essay but well.......  When Garou first got introduced I thought he's just gonna be some unimportant villain, I didn't really care about him but that quickly changed as we got to know more. Since his childhood he kept wondering why the villains/monsters are always the ones to lose. I mean in a world like they live in heroes are being worshipped to an extreme and some don't even deserve all that glory 'cos not everyone's doing it with good intentions. E.g. Fubuki at first only wanted to climb up the ranking (not saying I don't like her or her intentions are all bad) but that just shows how different the priorities of a hero can be.  Then there are the villains who're not all simply evil. Like some say Garou is a villain but I can't just view it black and white like that. He's even gone that far to become a monster, but no matter how much he's convinced himself he's one, you can still see his human side in the interactions with that little boy. It's hard to define him, that's why I don't really refer to him as a villain.  So after Garou got abducted by that birdman, you'll only come to like him even more in the manga. His steadfastness in his own convictions and values is really admirable.  He's now definitely become one of my favourite characters (bonus points for him being such a badass üòÇ).

comment: keilante taylor If i recall Correctly, the HA put out a request and the two of them answered it. The HA was monitoring them to provide support and send requests for extra aid if needed. And, again, Goldenball is a pretty impressive hero either way. He managed to hit Garou during their brief fight and has shown to have several superhuman abilities (reflexes, speed, strength). His slingshot is powerful enough to punch through steel, something many guns (of a similar size as his slingshot) cannot do consistently or at all. He can easily calculate multiple complicated ricochets on the fly. A gun would only hold him back.

(now some games have both stam and mana but just remember mana or MP is used for magic skills just like stam is for physical (MP tends to be just that or something akin to that game/anime what's evers universe aka its name can change and effects from overuse do as well but often it's just no spells) i hope i helped.
